content.description: In pea seeds, yellow color (<math alttext="uppercase Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) is dominant to green color (<math alttext="lowercase y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>), and a round shape (<math alttext="uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) is dominant to a wrinkled shape (<math alttext="lowercase r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>). A dihybrid cross between a true-breeding plant with yellow, round seeds <math alttext="uppercase Y uppercase Y uppercase R uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>Y</mi><mi>Y</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>R</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and a true-breeding plant with green, wrinkled seeds (<math alttext="lowercase y lowercase y lowercase r lowercase r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mi>y</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) results in an <math alttext="F 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> generation of plants with yellow, round seeds. Crossing two <math alttext="F 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> plants produces an <math alttext="F 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> generation with approximately nine times as many plants with yellow, round seeds as plants with green, wrinkled seeds.
content.question: Which of the following best explains these results?

choices.label: The allele pairs of each parent stay together, resulting in gametes that are identical to the parents.
Gene segments on sister chromatids cross over.
Alleles that are on nonhomologous chromosomes recombine.
The genes for seed color and seed shape assort independently.

content.answer: The genes for seed color and seed shape assort independently.
